It is said:
Is the Dharma body of all buddhas said to be differentiated or undifferentiated?
Because there is no difference in support, intention, and activity, it cannot be said to be differentiated;
Because of the immeasurable perfect enlightenment, there is differentiation.
Just as with the Dharma body, the enjoyment body is also like this. Because there is no difference in intention, use, and activity, there is no differentiation;
Because there is differentiation in support.
The transformation body should also be understood in the same way as the enjoyment body.
The commentary says:

As for because there is the transformation of immeasurable supports, bodhisattvas have immeasurable supports. Because the enjoyment body manifests due to this, therefore there is no difference in intention, use, and activity, but there is a difference in the matter of the body.
Among them, the undifferentiated mental function refers to the mind of benefiting all sentient beings, which should be known.
The undifferentiated activity refers to the activity of manifesting perfect enlightenment, parinirvÄá¹‡a, and so forth. This activity is undifferentiated, which should be known.
The treatise says:
It should be known that the Dharma body is associated with how many merits?

It is associated with the most pure four immeasurables, liberations, spheres of mastery, spheres of totality, absence of conflict, cognition of the aspiration, four unobstructed [abilities], six supernormal knowledges, thirty-two marks of a great person, eighty minor marks, four kinds of purity in all aspects, ten powers, four kinds of fearlessness, three things that need not be guarded, three foundations of mindfulness, the quality of nonforgetfulness, the elimination of habitual tendencies, great compassion, eighteen distinctive qualities of a buddha, and the supreme cognition of all aspects, and so forth.
There is a verse on this:
Compassionate toward all sentient beings, abandoning the mind bound by afflictions,
Not abandoning the mind of bliss, I take refuge in the mind of benefit.
Liberated from all obstructions, the Sage is supreme in the world,
With wisdom pervading the flames, I take refuge in the liberated mind.
Able to extinguish all the afflictions of sentient beings without remainder,
Those with afflictions return to suffering together, I take refuge in the one free from afflictions.
Effortless, unattached, unobstructed, and tranquil,
Always resolving all difficulties, I take refuge in the one who resolves difficulties.
The basis and what is based on it, the words and the wisdom they express,
The mind is always unobstructed, I take refuge in the one who speaks well.
Following their words, practicing going and coming, leaving and departing,
Knowing those sentient beings, I take refuge in the one who teaches well.
When sentient beings see the Buddha, it is due to the marks of a great person,
Merely seeing him gives rise to faith, I take refuge in the one who gives rise to faith.
Grasping, abiding, relinquishing, transformation, and transformation,
SamÄdhi, wisdom, and mastery, I take refuge in those who have reached the other shore.
Skillful means, refuge, purity, and the MahÄyÄna's liberation,
The obstacles of all sentient beings, I take refuge in the one who subdues MÄra.
Able to speak of wisdom and severance, liberating from obstructive matters,
Non-Buddhists cannot destroy, I take refuge in the one who benefits self and others.
Speaking the Dharma and subduing the great assembly, far removing the two afflictions,
Without protection and without forgetfulness, I take refuge in the one who gathers the assembly.
Benefiting all sentient beings, what is done is not untimely,
What is done is always not in vain, I take refuge in the one without forgetfulness.
Walking, standing, and in all places, there is no non-perfect wisdom activity,
At all times and everywhere knowing, I take refuge in the one of true meaning.
During the six periods of day and night, observing the various worlds,
Endowed with great compassion, I take refuge in the one with beneficial intentions.
Cultivation, realization, wisdom, and activity,
Superior to all two vehicles, I take refuge in the most excellent one.
The great enlightenment of the three bodies, endowed with all aspects,
I take refuge in the one who cuts off the doubts of all sentient beings in all places.
Fearless, faultless, untainted, and without abode,
Unmoved by any phenomena, I take refuge in the one beyond conceptual proliferation.
The Dharma body of the buddhas is endowed with such merits.
Moreover, it has the merits of intrinsic nature, cause, effect, activity, association, and function, and so forth. Therefore, the Dharma body of the buddhas is of unsurpassed merit, one should know.
Here there is a verse:
Accomplishing the most excellent meaning, surpassing all stages,
Reaching the summit of all sentient beings, liberating all sentient beings.
Infinite and unequaled merits, associated with the seen world,
The assembly of wheels also cannot be seen, nor can all gods and humans.
The commentary states:
The Dharma body is endowed with such merits.
There are also merits such as the essence, cause, effect, activity, and function. Among them, the essence of the Dharma body is revealed through the accomplishment of supreme meaning.
The accomplishment of supreme meaning refers to pure suchness, which is the essence of the Buddha.
The cause is revealed as transcending all stages, meaning that by cultivating all stages one attains the essence of the Buddha.
Reaching the highest among all beings reveals the effect, showing that this effect is the highest among all beings.
Liberating all beings reveals the activity, as the Buddha is the savior and liberator of all beings.
Endowment refers to being endowed with inexhaustible and unequaled merits, which is revealed by this.
Among them, seen by the world means seeing the transformation body.
The assembly of great beings sees means that they see the enjoyment body.
These gods and humans also do not see means that this assembly of great beings does not see the essential body.
This shows the distinctions in the activities of the Buddha's bodies.
The treatise says:
The Dharma body of all Buddhas is very profound, the most profound.
How can this profundity be seen?
There is a verse on this:
The Buddhas are unborn yet born, with nowhere to abide as their abode,
All activities are effortless, enjoying the fourth food.
Without distinctions, immeasurable, with immeasurable single activity,
Immovable and moving activity, the Buddhas are endowed with three bodies.
There is no realization of perfect enlightenment, yet it is not the case that all are not enlightened,
Moment by moment, immeasurable, with existence and non-existence manifesting.
Without desire, without being free from desire, yet also together with desire,
Having known desire is not desire, one can enter the suchness of the dharma of desire.
The buddhas transcend the aggregates, yet they also abide within the aggregates,
Not the same or different from them, not abandoning while in quiescent extinction.
The buddhas have the same activities, just like the waters of the great ocean,
I have already, am presently, and will act for the benefit of others, without such thoughts.
Sinners do not see it, like the moon in a broken vessel,
Universally pervading all worlds, the light of the dharma is like the sun.
Sometimes manifesting perfect enlightenment, sometimes nirvÄá¹‡a like a fire,
The tathÄgata's eternal body is unborn and also not existent.
The Buddha, in the non-correct dharma, among humans and evil destinies,
In the non-brahmacarya dharma, himself abiding in the supreme one.
Acting in all places, yet also without any action,
Seen by all beings, yet not an object of the six sense faculties.
Subjugating and severing all afflictions, like a spell controlling poisons,
Using afflictions to reach the end of afflictions, the Buddha possesses omniscience.
Afflictions are precisely bodhi, the essence of birth and death is quiescent extinction,
Because of having great skillful means, the TathÄgata is inconceivable.

This is precisely the twelve kinds of profundity that should be known, namely, the profundity of generation, completion, activity, and abiding, the profundity of establishing number and activity, the profundity of perfect enlightenment, the profundity of detachment, the profundity of the extinction of the aggregates, the profundity of maturation, the profundity of manifestation, the profundity of displaying perfect enlightenment and parinirvÄá¹‡a, the profundity of abiding, the profundity of displaying one's own body, the profundity of extinguishing afflictions, and the profundity of inconceivability.
The commentary states:
Now, we should reveal the profundity of the Great Vehicle, which is precisely revealing the twelve kinds of profundity.
Among them, the profundity of generation, completion, activity, and so forth is revealed in one verse.
The buddhas are born without being born shows the profundity of birth, because the buddhas are born without being born.
The abode is without abode shows the profundity of growth, because the buddhas do not abide in the abode of saá¹ƒsÄra or nirvÄá¹‡a.
Their activity is effortless shows the profundity of activity, because the buddhas' activity is equality, and their activity is equally enjoyed everywhere due to being effortless.

The fourth food shows the profundity of abiding, because the four kinds of food are the abode of the impure body. The buddhas are not the abode of the impure body, because the four foods such as morsels are the impure abode of the beings of the desire realm.

The pure and impure bodies abide refers to the beings of the form and formless realms. They are pure in regard to the afflictions of the lower realms, but impure in regard to the afflictions of the higher realms.
These pure and impure bodies only have the three foods of touch, intention, and consciousness, apart from the food of morsels. Their bodies can abide by relying on those three foods.
The support of pure bodies refers to the four foods such as morsels. For Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and so forth, these pure bodies abide in the world by relying on this support.
The support of manifestation refers to the four foods such as morsels that are manifested. It is precisely by relying on this support that the Buddhas eat. This is the fourth.

Because it is manifested and relied upon as a support, the World-Honored Buddhas accept the offerings of sentient beings and bring them joy, accumulating merit and virtue, and thus have no need for the function of food.
Moreover, some say:
When the Buddhas eat, the devas receive it and offer it to other sentient beings.
By this cause and condition, they cause those sentient beings to attain enlightenment.
These are all of one verse and of the same profundity.

Moreover, the characteristics of the Buddhas' birth should be known through ten causes: first, because of the distinction of ignorance; second, because of the various distinctions; third, because of the mastery of inclusion; fourth, because of the mastery of abiding; fifth, because of the mastery of relinquishment; sixth, because of the non-dual characteristic; seventh, because of being only an image; eighth, because of being like an illusion; ninth, because of abiding in non-abiding; and tenth, because of accomplishing the meaning of clouds.

It should be known that for ten causes the TathÄgata does not abide in either saá¹ƒsÄra or nirvÄá¹‡a: first, because of non-knowledge; second, because of non-extinction; third, because of non-existence; fourth, because of the non-existence of the wisdom of self-nature; fifth, because of non-attainment and non-discrimination; sixth, because of being apart from the mind; seventh, because of attaining the mind; eighth, because of the equality of the mind; ninth, because of not attaining objects; and tenth, because of non-non-attainment.

There are ten reasons why the buddhas accomplish buddha-work effortlessly: first, because of extinction and separation; second, because of no reliance; third, because of effortless activity; fourth, because of effortless agency; fifth, because of effortless action; sixth, because of effortless non-existence; seventh, because of no difference from the past; eighth, because of the completion of what is to be done; ninth, because of the incompleteness of what is to be done; tenth, because of mastery over all dharmas through thorough cultivation.

There are ten reasons why the Buddhas accept food: first, to demonstrate that the body is sustained by food; second, to cause sentient beings to accumulate merit; third, to demonstrate the same activities as sentient beings; fourth, to cause them to learn to eat properly; fifth, to cause them to learn contentment; sixth, to cause others to generate diligence; seventh, to mature wholesome roots; eighth, to manifest their own non-attachment; ninth, to uphold the honored karma; tenth, to fulfill their original vows.
Next, it reveals the verses on the profundity of the establishment of number and karma.
As for without distinction and immeasurable, this is the profundity of establishment.
Among them, without distinction means that the Dharma body is without distinction.
Immeasurable means that immeasurable bodies realize enlightenment, so there is no fixed number.
One karma is the profundity of number. Although the vehicles are immeasurable, because the Buddhas have one karma.

As for the two bodies of the buddhas being endowed with immovable and moving activities, although the buddhas are associated with the three bodies, the activities of the enjoyment body are firmly established, while the activities of the transformation body are not firmly established. This is precisely the profound meaning.
Next, it reveals the profundity of realizing perfect enlightenment in verses.
There is no one who realizes perfect enlightenment, because neither the person nor the Dharma exists.
It is not that there is no enlightenment of all, because enlightenment of all is spoken of conventionally.
What is this perfect enlightenment?
The verse says in every moment, immeasurable, which reveals that in every moment, immeasurable people attain perfect enlightenment.
Existence and non-existence are revealed means this reveals that suchness is not existent in all existences.
Next, it reveals the profundity of detachment in verses.
There is no desire and no detachment from desire, because desire does not exist, there is no defilement, and since there is no defilement, there is also no detachment.
Why is this?
If desire existed, then there could be detachment from desire.
Yet also together with desires means that by only cutting off the upper level of mental desires, one retains the latent desires.
If one does not retain the latent desires, then one would be the same as the Å›rÄvakas entering nirvÄá¹‡a.

Knowing that desire is not desire, one enters the suchness of the Dharma of desire means that within the discernment of desire, one clearly knows that it is not desire, and thus enters the true suchness of the Dharma of desire.
Next, the verse reveals the profundity of the extinction of the aggregates.

The buddhas transcend the aggregates yet also abide within the aggregates means that they have already transcended the five appropriated heaps such as form, but only abide within the heap of the suchness of the Dharma of no attainment.

They are neither the same as nor different from them means that the buddhas have already abandoned the appropriated heaps of discrimination, yet they are not different from them, because they abide precisely within the suchness of that Dharma;
yet they are also not the same, because although it is the transformation body, discrimination precisely becomes the pure realm.
Not abandoning yet quiescent extinction means that they do not abandon the heap of the true nature, which is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a.
Next, the verse reveals the profundity of maturation.
As for the same activities of all Buddhas, the activities of all Buddhas are equal, all for the sake of maturing sentient beings.
What is this like?
It is like the water of the great ocean, which, once entered, is used by fish, turtles, and others.
In the same way, once entered into the Dharma realm, it is equally for the sake of maturing sentient beings.

As for the absence of the thought I have already, am presently, or will in the future benefit others, there is not a single thought of contemplating benefiting sentient beings in the three times, yet it is like a maá¹‡i jewel or a heavenly drum without any effort, accomplishing the work of benefiting sentient beings.
Next, it reveals the verses on the profundity of manifestation.
If the world does not see the Buddhas, and it is said that the Buddhas are bodies of permanence;
Since there are bodies of permanence, why are they not seen?
The verse says, Sinners do not see them, like the moon in a broken vessel.
Just as when a vessel is broken, water does not remain, and because the water does not remain, the moon does not appear.
Thus, for these sentient beings who lack the nourishment of samÄdhi, the Buddha-moon does not appear.
Water is a metaphor for samÄdhi, because it nourishes.
The light of the Dharma pervades all worlds, just like the sun. Even if one does not see the Buddha, the Buddha still performs Buddha-works.
By expounding the sÅ«tras and other teachings, which are like sunlight, this is considered Buddha-work, and sentient beings can be brought to maturity in the world.
Next, it reveals the profundity of manifesting perfect enlightenment and parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Either manifesting perfect enlightenment or parinirvÄá¹‡a, like fire, means either manifesting perfect enlightenment or manifesting parinirvÄá¹‡a, the matter is like fire.
It is like fire, which sometimes burns and sometimes goes out.

The buddhas are also like this. For some sentient beings who should be brought to maturity through parinirvÄá¹‡a, they manifest parinirvÄá¹‡a; for those who should be brought to maturity through perfect enlightenment, they manifest perfect enlightenment, in order to bring about liberation.
Just as the nature of fire is not different, the one Dharma-body is also like this. It should be understood in this way.
The meaning of the remaining half of the verse can be understood.
Next, the verses revealing the profundity of abiding.

The Buddha abides in the supreme among non-correct human beings and evil destinies, and in non-brahmacarya dharmas himself. The supreme self-nature also abides supremely, because he abides in the holy abode.
Here, the holy abode refers to abiding in emptiness.
The heavenly abode refers to abiding in dhyana.
The brahma abode refers to abiding in the four immeasurables such as loving-kindness.
Non-correct dharmas refer to all unwholesome dharmas.
The Buddhas abide in emptiness within all unwholesome dharmas, and therefore the Buddhas abide in the holy abode.
They abide in dhyana while taking sentient beings in the human realm and evil destinies as their objects, which is the heavenly abode.
Within non-brahmacarya dharmas, they abide in the supreme self-nature.
It is like this.
The abode of emptiness is precisely the self-nature.
Next, the verses revealing the profundity of manifesting the self-nature.

In all places, there is no place where it does not go. The subsequently attained wisdom gives rise to distinctions between good and evil, etc., but if it is non-discriminating wisdom, then there is nowhere it does not go.
The transformation body goes everywhere, not the other bodies.
In the second meaning, all sentient beings see it means that this transformation body can be seen everywhere.

However, it is not the object of the six sense faculties. When this transformation body is seen by sentient beings in the hells, it is in order to teach and transform them that it is born in that place, not the intrinsic nature of the transformation body itself.
When those sentient beings in the hells see it, they think it is a hell body, and therefore it is not the object of the six sense faculties of those sentient beings in the hells, etc.
Next, the verse reveals the profundity of extinguishing afflictions.

Subduing and eliminating all afflictions is like a spell controlling poisons means that while the active afflictions are present during the bodhisattva stage, the afflictions are not eliminated because there are still latent afflictions.
It is like a spell controlling all poisons. It is like being poisoned, but the power of a spell controls it so that it does not cause harm.
Afflictions are also like this. Because of the knowledge of wisdom, they do not cause afflictions.
Using afflictions to reach the end of afflictions means that because of retaining the afflictions of remaining tendencies, it is not the same as the Å›rÄvakas entering parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The Buddha possesses all-encompassing knowledge means that when the afflictions of all buddhas are exhausted, they immediately attain the perfection of all-encompassing knowledge.
Next, the verse on the profundity of the inconceivable is shown.
These afflictions are precisely the factors of enlightenment, because they are the truth of accumulation.
The suffering of birth and death, etc., is precisely nirvÄá¹‡a.

All that is spoken by the TathÄgata is inconceivable, as explained above by the three kinds of causes and conditions, namely, only self-realization, etc., which are not the realm of conceptual thought.
The treatise says:
By how many kinds of mindfulness do bodhisattvas contemplate the Dharma body of the Buddha?
In brief, there are seven kinds of mindfulness that bodhisattvas cultivate in contemplating the Buddha:
First, all buddhas attain mastery over all dharmas, and should thus cultivate mindfulness of the Buddha, because they attain unobstructed spiritual powers and wisdom in all worlds.
Here there is a verse:
Obstructions, lack of causes, and pervasiveness throughout the realm of sentient beings,
Due to these two kinds of definitiveness, buddhas have no mastery.
Second, the body of the TathÄgata is eternally abiding, because suchness is uninterrupted and free from defilements.
Third, the TathÄgata is utterly free from blame, because he is free from all afflictive obstructions and obstructions to knowledge.
Fourth, the TathÄgata is effortless, because he does not abandon any buddha-work even without making any effort.
Fifth, the TathÄgata has great enjoyment, because the pure buddha-land is for his great enjoyment.
Sixth, the TathÄgata is undefiled, because he is born in the world but is not tainted by any worldly dharmas.

Seventh, the great meaning and benefit of the Tathagata is revealed, such as manifesting perfect enlightenment and entering nirvana, maturing sentient beings who are not yet mature, and liberating those who are already mature.
Here there is a verse:
Following one's own mind, always endowed with pure correspondence,
Without further effort, bestowing the great Dharma joy,
Without reliance, universally practicing, equally for many people,
All buddhas, the wise person thus contemplates.
The commentary states:
If bodhisattvas contemplate the Dharma body of the buddhas, they should cultivate mindfulness in seven ways. Now, the meaning of this cultivation will be revealed.

Among them, attaining mastery over all dharmas means attaining mastery over all dharmas through spiritual powers, because the buddhas attain unobstructed spiritual powers in all worlds, unlike the sravakas who have obstructions.
If all buddhas have mastery over all dharmas, why do not all sentient beings attain nirvÄá¹‡a?
This meaning is shown by the verse.
Because there are causes and conditions that prevent them from attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, it is said that there are obstacles and lack of causes, etc.

Here, obstacles means that because they are obstructed by karmic obstacles, etc., even innumerable buddhas cannot enable them to attain nirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, the buddhas have no such mastery over those sentient beings.
Lack of causes means lacking the nature of nirvÄá¹‡a.
This is the lack of causes, because of lacking that nature.
Because of the two kinds of determination, determination has two kinds:
one is the determination of karma, and the other is the determination of receiving retribution.
However, the buddhas have no mastery over these two kinds of determination.
Among them, the obstacle of retribution refers to dullness, etc., which should be known.
The determination of receiving retribution refers to definitely heading towards hell, etc.
The difference between retribution and receiving retribution is as follows.

The eternal body refers to true suchness, which is uninterrupted and free from defilements. This suchness is eternal, and this is taken as the body, therefore it is called the eternal body of the TathÄgata.
The great enjoyment of the TathÄgata refers to the fact that the TathÄgatas take the pure buddha-lands as their great enjoyment.

The great benefit refers to the essence of the great benefit of the buddhas, which is to mature and liberate those sentient beings who are not yet mature. By means of bodhi and nirvÄá¹‡a, they bring them to maturity, therefore it should be known.
The meaning of the other four aspects of contemplating the Buddha can be understood.
These seven kinds of contemplating the Buddha are further revealed by two verses.
In the verse following one's own mind and so forth, the seven characteristics are explained.
The bodhisattvas first contemplate that the fruition of the buddhas all follow one's own mind, and this is also eternal.
Purity and accord refer to goodness, and therefore it is most free from blame.
Effortlessness refers to accomplishing the affairs of the buddhas without effort.
Bestowing the great joy of the Dharma means the pure Buddha land should be known.

Without support, acting everywhere means if there is support in practicing, then it is suffering. Therefore, the Buddhas have no support and act in teaching and transforming. For this reason, they benefit many people.
Because it is shared by many people, the bodhisattvas should keep this in mind as their reward.
The treatise says:
Next, how should one understand the characteristics of the purity of the Buddha lands?
As it is said in the Hundred Thousand Verses Sutra, in the Bodhisattva Canon, in the chapter on causes and conditions, the BhagavÄn abides in
the supreme light, adorned with the seven treasures, therefore emitting great light, illuminating immeasurable worlds
, abiding in the place of immeasurable wonderful adornments, therefore being boundless in circumference, transcending
the realm of the three realms, arising from the supreme wholesome roots of the world, the most pure,
self-existing, characterized by consciousness, upheld by the TathÄgata, the abode of the great bodhisattvas, free from
The extent of the practices of devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, asuras, garuá¸as,
kiá¹ƒnaras, mahoragas, humans, non-humans, and so forth, the great Dharma taste
is sustained by bliss, it abides in all beings, in all beneficial activities, it is
free from all afflictions and oppressions, it is free from all mÄras, it surpasses all adornments
and abides in the TathÄgata's adornments, it gives rise to great mindfulness, wisdom, and practices, it takes as its vehicle the great Å›amatha
and vipaÅ›yanÄ, it enters the great emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness,
it is established in the great jeweled lotus king that is adorned with immeasurable merit and virtue, it roams in the great
palace.

Such phrases reveal the pure buddha land, namely, the perfection of form, the perfection of characteristics, the perfection of magnitude, the perfection of location, the perfection of causes, the perfection of effects, the perfection of masters, the perfection of companions, the perfection of retinues, the perfection of abodes, the perfection of activities, the perfection of harmonious inclusion, the perfection of fearlessness, the perfection of dwellings, the perfection of paths, the perfection of vehicles, the perfection of gates, and the perfection of supports. In this way, all are revealed.
Moreover, in that pure buddha land, all karmic rewards are exclusively pure and wonderful, exclusively blissful, exclusively free from vexation, and exclusively sovereign.
The commentary states:
As explained in the context of the sutra of a hundred thousand verses, the purity of the buddha land.
By what kind of superior merits is that pure buddha land revealed?
The first two lines reveal the perfection of form, namely, the seven treasures and so forth.
Among the seven treasures, gold, silver, lapis lazuli, coral, and agate are all included in stones, and malachite and other jade-like substances are also included in stones.
Red jewels refer to red pearls, which come from red insects, because pearls are produced from them. This pearl treasure is the most excellent of all treasures.
The light illuminates immeasurable worlds, because the light of the seven treasures mentioned above is produced. This is the second sentence on the perfection of form.
The next sentence shows the perfection of adornments, the next sentence shows the perfection of size, and the next sentence shows the perfection of location.
What is the cause of these?

The two kinds of wholesome roots produced by the supramundane nondiscriminating cognition and the post-attainment nondiscriminating cognition of the supramundane are the cause, which is the perfection of cause, and this also has one sentence.
The next line shows the perfection of the result, because in that Buddha land, the most pure consciousness turns into the characteristics.
The next line shows the perfection of the master, the next line shows the perfection of the companions, and the next line shows the perfection of the retinue.
Within this perfection of the retinue, the mahoragas are also included among the dragons.
If one is able to maintain the body in the Pure Land, this is the perfection of maintenance, which is also shown by one line.
Having taken this as food, what other activities does one perform?
One merely accomplishes all the affairs that benefit all sentient beings.
This is also shown by one line, which displays the perfection of following and embracing, because in the Pure Land there is no afflictions and no suffering.
This is also shown by one line, which displays the fearlessness of having no adversaries there, because there are no demons.

In that buddha land there are no demons of the aggregates, demons of afflictions, demons of death, or celestial demons, therefore there is no fear. This one sentence is the perfection of fearlessness.
The next sentence reveals the perfection of abode.
By what path can one enter that pure buddha land?
The essence is the wisdom of hearing, contemplating, and cultivating in the Mahayana, which is the practice of great mindfulness and wisdom.
In sequence, this one sentence reveals the perfection of equipment.
What is the vehicle?
It is the vehicle that goes to that [land] through Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ. This one sentence reveals the perfection of the vehicle.
By what gate can one enter that land?
It is the gate of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness in the Mahayana. This one sentence reveals the perfection of the gate.
The next sentence reveals the perfection of support, just as the great earth is supported by the wind wheel.
What supports that pure buddha land?
It is supported by immeasurable merit, and by a great jeweled lotus flower. This phrase shows the perfection of support.
In that Pure Land, the karmic retribution is exclusively pure and wonderful, because there are no impure things such as excrement and filth there.
It is exclusively blissful, because there are only pleasant feelings there, and no painful or neutral feelings.
It is exclusively free from blame, because there is neither unwholesomeness nor neutrality there.
It is exclusively sovereign, because one relies on the power of one's own mind and does not depend on causes and conditions.
The treatise says:
Furthermore, it should be known that this Dharma realm of all Buddhas always has five activities.
The first is the activity of saving all sentient beings from afflictions, which means that those who are deaf, blind, insane, etc., are saved merely by seeing [the Buddha].
The second is the activity of saving from evil destinies, which means pulling [beings] out of unwholesomeness and establishing them in wholesomeness.

Third, the activity of saving from non-skillful means, as non-Buddhists and others seek liberation through non-skillful means, opening their understanding and establishing them in the Buddha's true teachings.
Fourth, the activity of saving from the view of self, in order to cause them to transcend the three realms, teaching them with the path.

Fifth, the activity of saving from vehicles, referring to bodhisattvas who practice other vehicles and indeterminate Å›rÄvakas, etc., establishing them and causing them to cultivate the Great Vehicle.
These five activities are the equal activities of all buddhas.
Here, a verse is spoken:
